current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To establish the Appalachian Forest National Heritage Area, and for other purposes.

committee-name.#text: Committee on Energy and Natural Resources

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

short-title.#text:
West Virginia National Heritage
			 Area Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited
			 as the
The table of contents of this Act is as follows:

toc-entry.#text:
Sec. 1. Short title; table of
				contents.
TITLE I—Appalachian Forest National Heritage Area

Sec. 103. Appalachian Forest National Heritage
				Area.

Sec. 105. Authorities, duties, and prohibition of the local
				coordinating entity.
Sec. 106. Authorities and duties of the Secretary.
Sec. 107. Relationship to other Federal agencies.

Sec. 108. Property owners and regulatory
				protections.

Sec. 201. Extension of the National Coal Heritage
				Area.

Sec. 202. Extension of the Wheeling National Heritage
				Area.

text.#text:
the Heritage
			 Area—

is comprised of
			 18 counties that are located in West Virginia and western Maryland; and

taken as a
			 whole—

demonstrates
			 landscapes that arose from patterns of human activity that were shaped by the
			 geography of the forested central Appalachian Mountains; and

there is a
			 national interest in protecting, conserving, restoring, promoting, and
			 interpreting the benefits of the Heritage Area for—

the residents of
			 the Heritage Area; and

visitors to the
			 Heritage Area;

with respect to
			 the economic development of the United States—

the timber
			 harvesting activities in the region helped fuel late 19th century and early
			 20th century industrial growth throughout the United States; and

prominent
			 industrialists of the region were also active in the national economy;

the rich culture
			 of central Appalachia—

is inextricably
			 tied to the forest land of the region;

significant
			 historical and cultural sites and resources located in the Heritage Area
			 include—

5 national
			 historic landmarks; and

segments of 4
			 National Scenic Byways and 1 All-American Road;

nationally
			 significant natural and physical resources in the Heritage Area include
			 spectacular natural, scenic, and recreational resources, featuring the core of
			 the central hardwood forest of the United States, which—

as a result of
			 sound forest management and protection of public land, grew from the original
			 cutting of the forest; and
includes—

the
			 remnants of old growth forests;

protected
			 wilderness areas;

14 national
			 natural landmarks;

Federal and
			 State forest lands that were created to foster the regrowth of the forests of
			 the United States, including the Monongahela National Forest, and 9 State
			 forests;

experimental
			 forests that demonstrate the evolution of forestry management;

forests managed
			 by public and private entities; and

local public and
			 private partnerships that are based on the visions of the community and region
			 are working together to promote the stewardship, enhancement, and
			 interpretation of the resources of the Heritage Area;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, local residents, organizations, and
			 governments support the establishment of a national heritage area; and
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: West Virginia National Heritage Area Act of 2013/s:101/ss:a/p:10

text.#text:
to promote the
			 goals described in

involvement by
			 the Federal Government would enhance the efforts to promote the cultural,
			 natural, historical, and recreational resources of the region that have been
			 made by—

the States of
			 West Virginia and Maryland;

political
			 subdivisions of the States of West Virginia and Maryland;

volunteer
			 organizations; and

private
			 businesses.

The
			 purposes of this title are—

to provide a
			 cooperative management framework to the States of West Virginia and Maryland,
			 the political subdivisions of those States, and the citizens of those States to
			 conserve, enhance, and interpret the significant features of the forest, land,
			 water, and structures of the Heritage Area; and

to foster a close
			 working relationship with all levels of government, the private sector, and the
			 local communities of the region to enable those communities—

to conserve the
			 heritage of those communities; and

to continue to
			 pursue economic opportunities for those communities.
In this title:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: West Virginia National Heritage Area Act of 2013/s:103/ss:a

term.#tail:
means the Appalachian
			 Forest National Heritage Area established by

The
			 term

Maryland;
			 and

West
			 Virginia.

There
			 is established the Appalachian Forest National Heritage Area.

The
			 Heritage Area shall include—

the Barbour,
			 Braxton, Grant, Greenbrier, Hampshire, Hardy, Mineral, Morgan, Nicholas,
			 Pendleton, Pocahontas, Preston, Randolph, Tucker, Upshur, and Webster Counties
			 of the State of West Virginia; and

the Allegany and
			 Garrett Counties of the State of Maryland.

A map of the Heritage Area shall be on file and available for
			 public inspection in the appropriate offices of—
the

the local
			 coordinating entity.

The Appalachian Forest Heritage Area, Inc.,
			 shall—

serve as the
			 local coordinating entity for the Heritage Area; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: West Virginia National Heritage Area Act of 2013/s:104/ss:a

text.#text:
oversee the
			 development of a management plan under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
for approval a management plan for
			 the Heritage Area.

text.#text:
Not later than 3 years after the date on which funds are
			 first made available to carry out this title, the local coordinating entity
			 shall develop and submit to the

The
			 management plan shall—

present
			 comprehensive policies, goals, strategies, and recommendations for—

presenting to the
			 citizens of the United States the heritage of the region; and

describe actions
			 that units of government, private organizations, and citizens recommend for the
			 protection, enhancement, interpretation, funding, management, and development
			 of the resources of the Heritage Area;
identify—

existing and
			 potential sources of Federal and non-Federal funding for the protection,
			 enhancement, interpretation, funding, management, and development of the
			 resources of the Heritage Area; and

economic
			 development strategies for the protection, enhancement, interpretation,
			 funding, management, and development of the resources of the Heritage
			 Area;
include—

an inventory of
			 the cultural, natural, historical, educational, scenic, and recreational
			 resources contained in the Heritage Area, including a list of property
			 that—

is
			 related to the themes of the Heritage Area; and

should be
			 protected, enhanced, managed, or developed;

a recommendation
			 of policies and strategies for resource management and protection, including
			 the development of intergovernmental cooperative agreements to manage and
			 protect the cultural, natural, historical, educational, scenic, and
			 recreational resources of the Heritage Area;

a program of
			 strategies and actions to implement the management plan that includes—

performance
			 goals;

resource
			 protection plans;

enhancement
			 strategies;

interpretation
			 strategies; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
and other Federal agencies
			 associated with the Heritage Area;

text.#text:
an analysis of,
			 and recommendations for, means by which Federal, State, and local programs may
			 best be coordinated to further the purposes of this title, including an
			 analysis of the role of the

a business plan
			 that—

describes the
			 role, operation, financing, and functions of—

the local
			 coordinating entity; and

each of the
			 major activities included in the management plan; and

provides
			 adequate assurances that the local coordinating entity has the partnerships and
			 financial and other resources necessary to implement the management plan;
			 and

an interpretive
			 plan for the Heritage Area; and

list any
			 revisions to the boundaries of the Heritage Area proposed by the local
			 coordinating entity and requested by the affected local government.

, the local coordinating entity shall submit the management plan
			 to the

header.#text:
Authorities,
			 duties, and prohibition of the local coordinating entity

text.#text:
To
			 prepare and carry out the management plan, the local coordinating entity may
			 use funds made available under this title to—

make grants
			 to—

political
			 jurisdictions;

nonprofit
			 organizations; and

other parties
			 located in the Heritage Area;

enter into
			 cooperative agreements with, or provide technical assistance to—

political
			 jurisdictions;

nonprofit
			 organizations;

Federal agencies;
			 and

other interested
			 parties;

hire and
			 compensate staff who have demonstrated expertise in the fields of—

cultural,
			 natural, and historical resources conservation;

economic and
			 community development; or

heritage
			 planning;

obtain funds from
			 any source (including a program that has a cost-sharing requirement);

contract for
			 goods or services; and

support
			 activities of partners, and any other activities, that—

further the
			 purposes of the Heritage Area; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: West Virginia National Heritage Area Act of 2013/s:104/ss:d/p:1

text.#text:
are consistent
			 with the management plan approved under

In
			 addition to developing the management plan, the local coordinating entity
			 shall—

for any fiscal
			 year for which Federal funds have been received by the local coordinating
			 entity under this title—

submit an annual
			 report to the

the expenses and
			 income of the local coordinating entity;

the amounts and
			 sources of matching funds;

the amounts
			 leveraged with Federal funds and the sources of the leveraging; and

any grants made
			 to any other entities during the fiscal year; and

make available
			 for audit by

encourage, by
			 appropriate means and consistent with the purposes of the Heritage Area, the
			 economic viability of the Heritage Area.

The local coordinating entity
			 shall not use Federal funds made available under this title to acquire real
			 property or any interest in real property.

			 the

the development

other initiatives
			 of the local coordinating entity.

may enter into cooperative agreements with the local
			 coordinating entity and other public and private entities to provide assistance
			 under

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: West Virginia National Heritage Area Act of 2013/s:106/ss:a

text.#text:
To carry out this
			 title, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: West Virginia National Heritage Area Act of 2013/s:106/ss:b/p:1

text.#text:
The
			 cooperative agreement under

establish the
			 goals and objectives of the Heritage Area; and
include—

a
			 general outline describing each measure agreed to by the

This title shall not affect the authority of any Federal
			 official to provide technical or financial assistance under any other
			 law.

The head of any Federal agency planning to
			 conduct an activity that may have an impact on the Heritage Area shall, to the
			 maximum extent practicable—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and the local coordinating entity regarding the activity; and

text.#text: consult with the

coordinate the
			 activity with the
Nothing in this title—

limits the
			 discretion of a Federal land manager to implement an approved land use plan
			 within the boundaries of the Heritage Area; or

modifies, alters,
			 or amends any authorized use of Federal land under the jurisdiction of a
			 Federal agency.

Nothing in this title shall be construed
			 to—

abridge the rights of any property owner,
			 whether public or private, including the right to refrain from participating in
			 any plan, project, program, or activity conducted within the Heritage
			 Area;

require any property owner to permit public
			 access (including Federal, Tribal, State, or local government access) to such
			 property or to modify any provisions of Federal, Tribal, State, or local law
			 with regard to public access or use of private lands;

alter any duly adopted land use regulation
			 or any approved land use plan or any other regulatory authority of any Federal,
			 State, or local agency or Tribal government, or to convey any land use or other
			 regulatory authority to any local coordinating entity;

authorize or imply the reservation or
			 appropriation of water or water rights;

diminish the authority of the State to
			 manage fish and wildlife including the regulation of fishing and hunting within
			 the Heritage Area; or

create any liability, or to have any effect
			 on any liability under any other law, of any private property owner with
			 respect to any persons injured on such private property.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall conduct an evaluation of the accomplishments
			 of the Heritage Area and prepare a report with recommendations for the
future role, if any, with respect to the Heritage Area.

analyze the Federal, State, local, and

review the management structure,

			 identifying the critical components for sustainability of the Heritage
			 Area.
